papers.abstract: Data are wielded to shape public opinion, particularly in electoral contexts where the role and veracity of information is questioned. This post-truth era is characterized by world events in which facts too often are obfuscated and evidential standards are abandoned. To study how data are used to influence pressing and divisive contemporary issues, this paper explores the rhetorical work that quantitative data are doing through the blogging practices of advocacy organizations during the highly-polarized month preceding the 2016 United States elections. We present results of a qualitative content analysis of the quantitative data used in 337 blog posts published by five pairs of conservative and liberal advocacy organizations over the course of the month leading up to the 2016 US elections. We identify key data rhetoric practices along partisan lines and contribute an analytic framework — evaluating ethos, pathos, and logos — that can be used to analyze the rhetorical use of data in other contexts. We then characterize two different imaginaries that come into conflict in this research: 1) the political imaginaries being promoted through organizational blogging and 2) the sociotechnical imaginary of the data economy, foregrounding differences in the epistemic value of data in each. We conclude by outlining research challenges and trajectories for future research within each of the two imaginaries of data.

events.Text: Data are wielded to shape public opinion, particularly in electoral contexts where the role and veracity of information is questioned. This post-truth era is characterized by world events in which facts too often are obfuscated and evidential standards are abandoned. To study how data are used to influence pressing and divisive contemporary issues, this paper explores the rhetorical work that quantitative data are doing through the blogging practices of advocacy organizations during the highly-polarized month preceding the 2016 United States elections.

We present results of a qualitative content analysis of the quantitative data used in 337 blog posts published by five pairs of conservative and liberal advocacy organizations over the course of the month leading up to the 2016 US elections. We identify key data rhetoric practices along partisan lines and contribute an analytic framework — evaluating ethos, pathos, and logos — that can be used to analyze the rhetorical use of data in other contexts. We then characterize two different imaginaries that come into conflict in this research: 1) the political imaginaries being promoted through organizational blogging and 2) the sociotechnical imaginary of the data economy, foregrounding differences in the epistemic value of data in each.

Agent: Five pairs of conservative and liberal advocacy organizations

Primary Object: Quantitative data used in 337 blog posts published by five pairs of conservative and liberal advocacy organizations

Context: Qualitative content analysis of the quantitative data used in 337 blog posts published by five pairs of conservative and liberal advocacy organizations over the course of the month leading up to the 2016 US elections.
Purpose: To evaluate the rhetorical use of data in other contexts and develop an analytic framework assessing ethos, pathos, and logos
Method: Conducting a qualitative content analysis of the quantitative data used in 337 blog posts...
Results: We identify key data rhetoric practices along partisan lines and contribute an analytic framework evaluating ethos, pathos, and logos.
Analysis: We then characterize two different imaginaries that come into conflict in this research: 1) the political imaginaries being promoted through organizational blogging and 2) the sociotechnical imaginary of the data economy, foregrounding differences in the epistemic value of data in each.
Challenge: Potential weakness lies in relying exclusively on textual evidence and the relatively small number of cases studied limiting generalizability.
Ethical: Issues raised concern the risk of objectification inherent in labeling data as 'valuable' versus acknowledging its complexity and nuance.
Implications: Our analytic framework may offer opportunities for other studies examining comparable phenomena and highlight ongoing debates concerning the ethics and effectiveness of data valuation in contemporary governance structures.

events.Text: We conclude by outlining research challenges and trajectories for future research within each of the two imaginaries of data.

Context: We conclude by outlining research challenges and trajectories for future research within each of the two imaginaries of data.
Purpose: To summarize prior work and lay out future directions for addressing research challenges within the two imaginaries of data.
Method: General discussions typical of literature reviews, without specifying particular methodologies employed.
Results: Outlining of research challenges and trajectories for future research within each of the two imaginaries of data.
Analysis: Interpretation involving identification of future research opportunities within the defined data imaginaries.
Challenge: Acknowledgment of limitations arising from focusing exclusively on currently understood data imaginaries, potentially overlooking alternative conceptualizations.
Implications: Potential contribution to expanding knowledge in data science by guiding future research toward less explored domains.

papers.abstract: This paper zooms in on a particularly precarious and largely invisibilized group of care workers: middle-aged and less-educated female migrant workers from rural China. Drawing from a mixed-methods study, we specifically examine how the extensive use of data-driven technologies impacts care workers' wellbeing in the workplace. Our findings suggest the extensive use of data-driven healthcare technologies are eroding care workers' workplace wellbeing, especially their sense of identity, agency, and perceived justice. Specifically, in the data-driven workplace, care workers are treated as a servant to data, instead of a human with agency and knowledge. They are no merely care workers who provide various care services for care receivers, but also data workers, whose practices and agency are greatly limited by data. This aggravates preexisting hardship of care workers, and reproduces new social injustice. We suggest CSCW researchers and practitioners take into account how pre-existing social structures shaped the designs of socio-technological systems, and reconceptualize the paradigm of 'data-drivenness' for more just and ethical data-driven healthcare technologies.

events.Text: Our findings suggest the extensive use of data-driven healthcare technologies are eroding care workers' workplace wellbeing, especially their sense of identity, agency, and perceived justice. Specifically, in the data-driven workplace, care workers are treated as a servant to data, instead of a human with agency and knowledge. They are no merely care workers who provide various care services for care receivers, but also data workers, whose practices and agency are greatly limited by data. events.Main Action: Care workers are no merely care workers

Context: Extensive use of data-driven healthcare technologies are eroding care workers' workplace wellbeing
Purpose: To explore the impact of data-driven technologies on care workers' wellbeing
Method: Qualitative studies involving interviews and surveys with care workers
Results: Findings reveal negative outcomes including decreased identity, agency, and perceived justice
Analysis: Interpretation of how these shifts manifest and affect daily operations within workplaces
Challenge: Balancing technological advancements with equitable work environments
Ethical: Concerns about respecting worker autonomy and dignity
Implications: Necessity of reevaluating policies concerning healthcare technology usage

events.Text: We suggest CSCW researchers and practitioners take into account how pre-existing social structures shaped the designs of socio-technological systems, and reconceptualize the paradigm of 'data-drivenness' for more just and ethical data-driven healthcare technologies.
